Award.AwardTitle: QuBBD: Collaborative Research: Towards Automated Quantitative Prostate Cancer Diagnosis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Subjective analyses of images by pathologist reviewers are plagued by issues of inter-rater variability and throughput. However, as digital pathology whole slide scanners become more commonplace, the amount of high-quality pathology image data available to researchers and clinicians is increasing, and the newfound widespread availability of pathology images in digital form, including the NCI Cancer Genome Atlas (TGCA), opens up new possibilities to use computational approaches to leverage the information inherent within them for diagnosis, prognosis, and precision medicine. This award supports initiation of a collaborative research project that aims to discover new quantitative image-based prognostic biomarkers for prostate cancer, focusing on an investigation of novel concepts from computational topology applied to prostate cancer glandular architecture.

The current standard for prostate cancer grading is the Gleason score, which is a subjective rating system based on an analysis of high-level tissue architecture and glandular shape and organization. However, Gleason scoring is variable between pathology reviewers, and may not capture all of the potentially prognostic information contained in glandular growth patterns. In this project, new topological descriptors will be developed that capture architectural features of prostate glands in pathology images. These descriptors can then be used to aid pathologists by providing more quantitative and more reproducible analogs to the traditional Gleason scores, and they may have independent prognostic value. They can also be used to classify slides in order to distinguish between different types of cancerous architectures of glands, compared to the current gold-standard histopathological and molecular characterization. In particular, the aim of this project is to demonstrate effectiveness of using computational methods based on tools from computational geometry and topology to recognize and quantify glandular architectural features. Glandular density will be the first architectural feature quantified in this collaborative work. This award is supported by the National Institutes of Health Big Data to Knowledge (BD2K) Initiative in partnership with the National Science Foundation Division of Mathematical Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Histopathology is the observation of the microscopic structure of tissue and cells in order to aid in clinical diagnosis of disease and evaluation of treatment, as well as in the basic study of disease. For most of its history, this field of study has relied on human interpretation of thin slices of tissues prepared on microscope slides. However, the recent introduction of new microscopy tools for creating digital images of these tissues has opened up the possibility of using computer-aided tools in the study and diagnosis of human disease. The objective of this project was to develop emerging mathematical concepts and computational tools for application in the computer-aided interpretation of histopathology images. Specifically, prostate cancer, which is one of the leading causes of cancer deaths, is evaluated for its aggressive potential by visual observation of looping structures created by the cancer cells - this is by the so-called Gleason score. The Gleason score is subjective and variable that can have important implications in cancer diagnosis and treatment. In this project, we applied topological data analysis (TDA) to the study of prostate cancer images. We found that TDA is sensitive to the microstructure of the prostate cancer, and that quantitative descriptors of prostate cancer architecture using TDA correlate well with clear differences in prostate cancer grade. However, we also found that TDA can uncover differences in the architecture of prostate cancers that are at the "borderline" between cancer grades. These provocative results indicate that TDA could be useful for more precise grading of prostate cancer that would have significant implications in prostate cancer diagnosis, treatment, and management.


In terms of Intellectual Merit, we have developed methods for the application and study of histopathology images using TDA, which could have significant implications not only in prostate cancer but in other diseases as well. The Broader Impacts of this study are manifold. In addition to the development of TDA for histopathology analysis of prostate cancer, the methods that we have developed could be widely applicable in TDA of cancers or diseases other than prostate cancer. In the project, we have provided training for several graduate students in the fields of topological data analysis, digital histopathology, and prostate cancer. Results of this project have been widely disseminated to the public in publications, conference presentations, seminars, and website materials, and elements of this project have been used in instructional materials. Interdisciplinary collaborations between computer scientists, mathematicians, biomedical engineers, and clinical pathologists have been cultivated due to this project to advance these technical achievements towards improvement of public health.
